articles.headline: Tension With Russia Rises as U.S. Halts Syria Negotiations
articles.snippet: The United States made good on a threat made last week, with the State Department calling it “not a decision that was taken lightly.”
articles.abstract: The United States made good on a threat made last week, with the State Department calling it “not a decision that was taken lightly.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States on Monday suspended talks with Russia over the protracted conflict in Syria, accusing the Kremlin of joining with the Syrian Air Force in carrying out a brutal bombing campaign against the besieged city of Aleppo.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: In Las Vegas, Rising Murders Strain a Police Force Used to Solving Them
articles.snippet: The city has an enviable record for clearing cases, but is fighting to keep up with the pace. “I’ve got a lot of tired people,” one officer said.
articles.abstract: The city has an enviable record for clearing cases, but is fighting to keep up with the pace. “I’ve got a lot of tired people,” one officer said.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — In the seven months since Heriberto Diaz Marcial was shot and killed walking home from his job as a casino porter on the Vegas Strip, church volunteers have knocked on hundreds of doors in his neighborhood and handed out fliers seeking information. The police released blurry security footage of a gray sedan tied to his three killers. His wife, Maria Diaz, has gone on television to plead for help.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy and Timothy Williams

articles.headline: Women Shun the Maternity Smock, and Stores Race to Catch Up
articles.snippet: The maternity aisle is looking more like a high-end boutique as cultural attitudes about pregnancy shift from bigger and baggier to sleeker and stretchier.
articles.abstract: The maternity aisle is looking more like a high-end boutique as cultural attitudes about pregnancy shift from bigger and baggier to sleeker and stretchier.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has been more than 25 years since Demi Moore bared her pregnant belly on the cover of Vanity Fair, but retailers are finally catching up to the fact that pregnant women do not always want to hide under a muumuu.

articles.headline: Judges Push Brevity in Briefs, and Get a Torrent of Arguments
articles.snippet: A proposal to cut the maximum word count of appellate briefs by 1,500 words, to 12,500, had lawyers fuming.
articles.abstract: A proposal to cut the maximum word count of appellate briefs by 1,500 words, to 12,500, had lawyers fuming.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Constitution of the United States clocks in at 4,543 words. Yet a number of lawyers contend that 14,000 words are barely enough to lay out their legal arguments.

articles.headline: Deep Scars and Complacency Defeated Colombia’s Peace Deal
articles.snippet: Months of polling had predicted a wide margin of victory for the agreement between the Colombian government and the FARC, the country’s largest rebel group.
articles.abstract: Months of polling had predicted a wide margin of victory for the agreement between the Colombian government and the FARC, the country’s largest rebel group.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEDELLÍN, Colombia — Laura Solano, a 25-year-old graphic design student, is the kind of young urbanite who Colombian leaders had hoped would support a peace deal with the country’s largest rebel group.
articles.byline: By Kirk Semple and Nicholas Casey

articles.headline: With Tim Kaine and Mike Pence, Faith Is Back in the Mix
articles.snippet: This campaign has largely been absent of the social issues that were at the heart of the country’s political divide for decades. That might change at Tuesday’s vice-presidential debate.
articles.abstract: This campaign has largely been absent of the social issues that were at the heart of the country’s political divide for decades. That might change at Tuesday’s vice-presidential debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The descent of the 2016 presidential campaign last week into the realm of sex tapes and marital infidelity was remarkable enough in its own right, but it also offered a reminder of what has been largely absent from the race: a debate about issues of public morality that for decades have been at the heart of the country’s political divide.

articles.headline: When It Comes to Tax Avoidance, Donald Trump’s Just a Small Fry
articles.snippet: A new study shows how Fortune 500 companies have managed to shelter trillions of dollars in profits offshore from being taxed, leaving Mr. Trump in the dust.
articles.abstract: A new study shows how Fortune 500 companies have managed to shelter trillions of dollars in profits offshore from being taxed, leaving Mr. Trump in the dust.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not paying taxes “makes me smart,” Donald J. Trump said last week. His surrogates called him “a genius” for his recently revealed tax avoidance strategies.

articles.headline: Why Referendums Aren’t as Democratic as They Seem
articles.snippet: Though such votes are portrayed as popular governance in its purest form, studies have found that they often subvert democracy rather than serve it.
articles.abstract: Though such votes are portrayed as popular governance in its purest form, studies have found that they often subvert democracy rather than serve it.
articles.lead_paragraph: The voters of the world have had quite a year: They rejected Colombia’s peace deal; split Britain from the European Union; endorsed a Thai Constitution that curtails democracy; and, in Hungary, backed the government’s plan to restrict refugees, but without the necessary turnout for a valid result.
articles.byline: By Amanda Taub and Max Fisher

articles.headline: Subpoenas and Gag Orders Show Government Overreach, Tech Companies Argue
articles.snippet: Open Whisper Systems received a subpoena for information on its Signal app subscribers and an order not to talk about it, a practice Microsoft and others say is too prevalent, and unconstitutional.
articles.abstract: Open Whisper Systems received a subpoena for information on its Signal app subscribers and an order not to talk about it, a practice Microsoft and others say is too prevalent, and unconstitutional.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It has been six months since the Justice Department backed off on demands that Apple help the F.B.I. break the security of a locked iPhone.
articles.byline: By Nicole Perlroth and Katie Benner

articles.headline: Next ‘Renewable Energy’: Burning Forests, if Senators Get Their Way
articles.snippet: The president’s Clean Power Plan is being fought by 28 states, and a bipartisan group of senators who want burning wood for electricity to be considered carbon neutral.
articles.abstract: The president’s Clean Power Plan is being fought by 28 states, and a bipartisan group of senators who want burning wood for electricity to be considered carbon neutral.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Obama’s Clean Power Plan — the central plank in his strategy to combat climate change — is in danger.
